query: To improve soil fertility, how does adding compost compare to adding manure?
relevant_summary: Both compost and manure improve soil fertility through similar mechanisms but with some differences in effects. For organic matter content, twelve studies found more organic matter in soils with added compost compared to soils without (Action 1362), while five studies found more organic matter in soils with added manure compared to soils without it, though three studies found similar amounts (Action 1363). Regarding nutrients, six studies found more nutrients in soils with added compost in some or all comparisons, though three studies found inconsistent nitrogen differences and one found no phosphorus differences (Action 1362). For manure, three studies found more nitrogen and two found more potassium in soils with added manure, while one found more phosphorus, though results were mixed for nitrogen in two studies and inconsistent for phosphorus in one study (Action 1363). For soil organisms, six studies found more microbial biomass in soils with added compost in some or all comparisons (Action 1362), while two studies found similar amounts of microbial biomass in soils with or without added manure (Action 1363). Both amendments reduce soil erosion and improve stability, with two studies showing less erosion and four showing greater stability with compost (Action 1362), and one study showing less erosion and three showing higher soil stability with manure (Action 1363). However, greenhouse gas emissions differ, with six studies finding more greenhouse gas emissions in soils with added compost (Action 1362), while one study found higher carbon dioxide emissions and one found higher nitrous oxide emissions with manure (Action 1363). Studies combining manures and agricultural composts found higher microbial biomass, reduced nutrient loss, higher nitrogen levels, increased organic carbon, and higher crop yields (Action 911).

query: What are the potential negative impacts of using no-tillage systems in arable fields in a Mediterranean climate?
relevant_summary: Based on studies from Mediterranean countries including Spain, Italy, and Portugal, several potential negative impacts of no-tillage systems in arable fields have been documented. Crop yield reductions are a significant concern, with multiple replicated, controlled studies from Spain showing lower cereal yields in no-tillage plots compared to reduced tillage in some comparisons (action 1358). Seven replicated, controlled studies from Italy, Lebanon, Spain, and the USA found lower crop yields in plots with no tillage compared to conventional tillage in some or all comparisons (action 1355). Specifically for fruits and vegetables, three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy found lower fruit or vegetable yields in plots with no tillage compared to reduced tillage in some comparisons (action 1358). One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found lower sunflower seed yields in plots with no tillage compared to reduced tillage in some comparisons (action 1358). Regarding crop quality, one replicated, controlled study from Italy found less protein in wheat grains from plots with no tillage compared to conventional tillage (action 1355). Soil compaction issues are another concern, as three replicated trials found higher compaction under reduced tillage (action 906). Weed management challenges may occur, with one replicated, controlled study from Australia finding more weeds in plots with no tillage compared to reduced tillage (action 1398). Regarding soil nutrients, six replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain found less nitrogen in soils without tillage in some or all comparisons (action 1369), and one replicated, randomized, controlled study from Portugal found less phosphorus in soils without tillage compared to soils with tillage in some comparisons (action 1369). Additionally, one replicated, randomized, controlled study from Portugal found lower pH levels in soils without tillage compared to soils with tillage in some comparisons (action 1369). Soil erosion may also be problematic, as two trials showed that no-tillage increased soil loss in the absence of crop cover (action 906).

A total of 42 individual studies (including seven replicated, controlled and randomized studies and six reviews) from Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Switzerland and the UK investigated the effects of reducing tillage on farmland wildlife. Thirty-four studies (of which 21 were replicated and controlled and seven also randomized, and five reviews) from nine European countries found some positive effects on earthworms, some invertebrates (other than earthworms), weeds or farmland birds, of reducing tillage compared to conventional management. Positive effects included increased biomass, species richness or abundance of earthworms, greater abundance of some invertebrates other than earthworms, increased numbers of some weeds and/or weed species, higher Eurasian skylark nest density, earlier laying date and shorter foraging distances on reduced tillage fields, and greater abundance of some birds - including Eurasian skylark, seed-eating songbirds and gamebirds in late winter on non-inversion or conservation tillage. A review found tillage had negative effects on invertebrate numbers and no-till systems had more invertebrate bird food resources.
Twenty-six studies (of which 13 replicated and controlled and three also randomized, and five reviews) from nine European countries found reducing tillage had either negative, no effect or no consistent effects on abundance, biomass, or species richness of some invertebrates (other than earthworms), earthworm abundance, biomass, or species richness, number of different plant species found as seeds, number of some weed species, mammal abundance, some bird species, and one study found bird preferences for conservation tillage fields decreased over time. Two studies found that crop type affected the number of weeds under different tillage regimes.
One small replicated trial in the UK compared bird numbers under two different forms of reduced tillage, and found more birds from species that make up the ‘Farmland Bird Index’ on broadcast than non-inversion tillage fields.
Two studies looked at the long-term effects of reduced tillage on earthworms (after ten years). One study found higher earthworm biomass under reduced tillage, the other study found earthworm abundance was the same between conventional and reduced tillage plots.
Three of the studies mentioned above did not distinguish between the effects of reducing tillage and reduced pesticide and/or fertilizer inputs."

query: For arable fields in the Mediterranean, how does a no-tillage system compare with a reduced tillage system for improving soil health?
relevant_summary:
Based on studies conducted in Mediterranean countries (primarily Spain and Italy), both no-tillage and reduced tillage systems show benefits for soil health compared to conventional tillage, with some differences between the two approaches:

**Organic Matter**: For no-tillage systems, one meta-analysis from Mediterranean countries and fourteen replicated studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found more organic matter compared to conventional tillage (Action 1369). For reduced tillage, one meta-analysis from Mediterranean countries and eleven replicated studies from Italy, Spain, Syria, and the USA found more organic matter compared to conventional tillage (Action 1371). When directly comparing the two systems, three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain found more organic matter in no-tillage compared to reduced tillage, while three other studies found similar amounts (Action 1370).

**Soil Structure and Aggregation**: No-tillage systems showed that seven replicated studies from Spain and the USA found soils were more stable than tilled soils (Action 1369). For reduced tillage, three replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain found soil aggregates had higher water-stability compared to conventional tillage (Action 1371). Direct comparison showed one study from Spain found more large aggregates and higher water-stability in no-tillage compared to reduced tillage in some comparisons (Action 1370).

**Soil Organisms**: Both systems support microbial biomass, with eleven replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA finding more microbial biomass in reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage (Action 1371), and five replicated, controlled studies from Italy and Spain finding more microbial biomass in no-tillage compared to conventional tillage (Action 1369). When comparing the two systems directly, five studies from Spain found similar amounts of microbial biomass between no-tillage and reduced tillage (Action 1370).

**Nutrients**: For nitrogen, six replicated studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found more nitrogen in no-tillage compared to conventional tillage, while seven studies found more nitrogen in reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage (Actions 1369, 1371). Direct comparison showed three studies from Italy and Spain found more nitrogen in no-tillage compared to reduced tillage in some comparisons (Action 1370).

**Water Management**: Nine controlled studies from Spain and the USA found more water in soils without tillage compared to conventional tillage (Action 1384), while six controlled studies from Egypt and Spain found more water in soils with reduced tillage compared to conventional tillage (Action 1386).

query: What are the potential drawbacks for crop production when planting ground cover in Mediterranean orchards or vineyards?
relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, several potential drawbacks for crop production when planting ground cover in Mediterranean orchards or vineyards have been identified:

**Reduced Crop Yields**: Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from France and the USA found lower grape yields in plots that were seeded with grass between the vine rows, compared to plots with bare soil between the vine rows, in some or all comparisons (Action 1352). One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Chile found lower avocado yields in plots that were seeded with grasses and legumes, compared to plots with bare soil (Action 1352). Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Portugal found lower chestnut yields in plots with seeded cover crops, compared to resident vegetation (Action 1352).

**Increased Water Competition**: Two replicated, controlled studies from the USA found that plants used more water in plots with ground cover, compared to plots with bare soil (Action 1382). Four studies from Spain and the USA found less water, or less available water in some comparisons, in soils with seeded cover crops, compared to tilled soils (Action 1382).

**Nutrient Competition**: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found less nitrogen in soils with ground cover, in some comparisons (Action 1367). Two studies from Spain and the USA found less phosphorus in soils with seeded cover crops, compared to tilled soils, in some comparisons (Action 1367).

**Increased Pest Damage**: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found that more grapes were damaged by pests in plots with cover crops, compared to bare fallows, in some comparisons (Action 1395). One replicated, controlled study from a vineyard in the USA found more weeds in plots with cover crops, compared to bare soil, in one of nine comparisons (Action 1395). One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found more navel orangeworm moths in plots with resident vegetation, compared to tilled soil, in one of two comparisons (Action 1395).

**Variable Crop Quality Effects**: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found lighter-weight clusters of grapes in plots with seeded cover crops, compared to resident vegetation, in one of three years (Action 1352). One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Portugal found smaller chestnuts and lower mushroom yields in plots with seeded cover crops compared to resident vegetation (Action 1352).

Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Portugal found lower chestnut yields in plots with seeded cover crops, compared to resident vegetation (Action 1352).

**Increased Water Competition**: Two replicated, controlled studies from the USA found that plants used more water in plots with ground cover, compared to plots with bare soil (Action 1382). **Nutrient Competition**: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found less nitrogen in soils with ground cover, in some comparisons (Action 1367). Two studies from Spain and the USA found less phosphorus in soils with seeded cover crops, compared to tilled soils, in some comparisons (Action 1367).

**Increased Pest Damage**: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found that more grapes were damaged by pests in plots with cover crops, compared to bare fallows, in some comparisons (Action 1395). One replicated, controlled study from a vineyard in the USA found more weeds in plots with cover crops, compared to bare soil, in one of nine comparisons (Action 1395). One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found more navel orangeworm moths in plots with resident vegetation, compared to tilled soil, in one of two comparisons (Action 1395).

**Variable Crop Quality Effects**: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found lighter-weight clusters of grapes in plots with seeded cover crops, compared to resident vegetation, in one of three years (Action 1352). query: What does the evidence say about how adding different organic amendments to soil affects greenhouse gas emissions on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary:
Evidence from Mediterranean farmland studies shows that different organic amendments have varying effects on greenhouse gas emissions. For slurry additions, most studies from Spain found higher nitrous oxide emissions compared to soils without slurry, with five out of six studies showing increased emissions in some or all comparisons (Action 1365). Carbon dioxide emissions from slurry showed mixed results, with two studies finding higher emissions while one found no difference (Action 1365). Methane effects were generally minimal, with three studies finding similar methane fluxes and one study finding reduced methane absorption (Action 1365). 

Compost additions to Mediterranean soils showed increased greenhouse gas emissions in most cases. Six studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found more greenhouse gas emissions in soils with added compost compared to soils without compost, though four studies from Spain found no differences (Action 1362).

When comparing organic versus inorganic fertilizers in Mediterranean contexts, the effects varied by gas type. For carbon dioxide, four studies from Italy and Spain found higher emissions from organic fertilizer plots compared to inorganic fertilizer, though one study found similar emissions (Action 1366). Nitrous oxide showed mixed results, with three studies finding lower emissions from organic fertilizer while five studies found similar emissions compared to inorganic fertilizer (Action 1366). For methane, two studies found that organic fertilizer soils absorbed more methane than inorganic fertilizer soils, while two studies found similar absorption rates (Action 1366).

Manure additions showed limited greenhouse gas data from Mediterranean studies, with one study from Spain finding higher nitrous oxide emissions and one from the USA finding higher carbon dioxide emissions compared to plots without manure (Action 1363). Sewage sludge additions resulted in higher carbon dioxide emissions according to two studies from Spain and the USA (Action 1364).

query: What are the effects of different soil amendments on soil organisms in Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: Based on the available action documents, several soil amendments show specific effects on soil organisms in farmland contexts. Mixed organic and inorganic amendments resulted in higher microbial biomass and activity in soils, with one trial finding increased microbial diversity (Action 902). Manures and agricultural composts increased microbial biomass and microbial respiration when applied (Action 911). Fresh plant material or crop remains increased microbial biomass when added to soil (Action 910). Adding bacteria or fungi to soil resulted in higher microbial diversity (Action 888), and mycorrhizal-inoculated compost applications increased soil organic matter content (Action 888). A study from Italy found that reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use generally resulted in higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms in low-input systems (Action 904). Cover crops or ground cover in perennial crops increased microbial biomass, symbiotic fungi (mycorrhizae), bacteria, and nematodes in soils (Action 2304). Organic farming showed higher numbers, diversity, functional diversity or activity of soil organisms (Action 895). Sewage sludge amendments showed similar amounts of microbial biomass in soils with or without added sewage sludge (Action 2303). Compost application at high rates increased microbial biomass (Action 889).

query: To improve water availability on my arable farm in a Mediterranean climate, what management practices can I use?
relevant_summary:
Several management practices can improve water availability on arable farms. Tillage practices play a crucial role: reduced tillage was found to increase water content in soils in some or all comparisons compared to conventional tillage, while crops used water more efficiently in plots with reduced tillage in some comparisons (Action 1386). No tillage was found to be even more effective, with more water found in soils with no tillage compared to reduced tillage in some or all comparisons, and crops using water more efficiently in one of four comparisons (Action 1385). Reduced tillage also increased water infiltration rates and reduced water loss through runoff in some comparisons (Action 1386), while no-tillage in the absence of crop cover increased soil loss (Action 906). 

Mulching practices significantly improve water retention: adding mulch to crops increased soil moisture according to two replicated trials from India (Action 887). Cover crops beneath the main crop or between crop rows reduced erosion and improved soil stability (Action 897), while retaining crop residues reduced water runoff and increased water storage according to one review (Action 907). 

Crop rotation, particularly including legumes, increased water infiltration in replicated trials from Syria (Action 857). Buffer strips can also help retain soil moisture, with one study finding more soil moisture in plots with buffers compared to plots without buffers in some comparisons (Action 1387).

query: How do habitat creation actions, such as planting hedgerows or restoring watercourses, impact biodiversity on Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence, habitat creation actions show mixed impacts on biodiversity in farmland settings, though specific Mediterranean studies are limited. For hedgerow planting, one study from Switzerland found that establishing hedgerows alongside arable land increased small mammal abundance (Action 2383). Seven studies from the UK, Ireland and Canada found that established hedgerows had higher species richness of butterflies and macro-moths compared to in-field beetle banks, crops or pasture, and higher abundance of butterflies, moths and macro-moths along hedgerows (Action 3976). For hedgerow management, ten studies from Switzerland and the UK found that managing hedges for wildlife resulted in increased berry yields, species diversity or richness of plants and invertebrates and diversity or abundance of farmland birds (Action 116).

For watercourse restoration, one study from Spain found similar numbers of bird species in restored and remnant riparian sites, while another from Spain found similar numbers of birds and bird species in restored contaminated sites and uncontaminated sites (Action 1416). Three studies from the Netherlands and the UK reported that riparian buffer strips had a positive influence on plant, invertebrate and bird diversity or abundance (Action 120).

Limited evidence from Mediterranean regions includes one study from Spain that found more birds and higher bird diversity in a vineyard with resident vegetation compared to bare soil between vine rows, and another Spanish study found more birds and higher bird diversity in a vineyard with mown resident vegetation compared to herbicide-treated vegetation (Action 1413). However, comprehensive evidence specifically examining habitat creation impacts on Mediterranean farmland biodiversity remains scarce in the available studies.

query: How do additions of compost, manure, and slurry compare in their effects on soil organic matter and nutrients in Mediterranean farmland?
relevant_summary: Based on studies from Mediterranean countries including Spain, Italy, Greece, Portugal, and Turkey, the three organic amendments show varying effects on soil organic matter and nutrients. For slurry additions (Action 1365), three studies from Spain and multiple Mediterranean countries found similar amounts of organic matter in soils with or without added slurry, while one Spanish study found more organic matter with slurry in some comparisons. Regarding nutrients, two Spanish studies found more nitrate in soils with added slurry, while two studies from Portugal and Spain found similar nitrate amounts. For manure additions (Action 1363), five studies from Italy, Tunisia, Turkey, and the USA found more organic matter in soils with added manure compared to soils without it, while three studies from Italy, Spain, and Greece found similar amounts of organic matter. Three studies from Italy and Tunisia found more nitrogen in soils with added manure in some comparisons, while two studies from Greece and Italy found similar nitrogen amounts. For compost applications (Action 911), four studies from India, Japan and the UK found higher carbon levels when manures were applied, and one study from Turkey found higher organic matter, larger soil aggregations and positive effects on soil physical properties when manure and compost were applied. However, two studies from Denmark and Germany found no effect of manure on organic matter levels. When comparing organic fertilizers (including compost and manure) to inorganic fertilizers (Action 1366), eight studies from France, Italy, Spain, Turkey, and Mediterranean countries found more organic matter with organic fertilizer in some comparisons, while five studies found similar amounts. One study from Italy found more organic matter, nutrients, and microbial biomass in plots fertilized with compost compared to manure, indicating compost may be superior to manure for these soil properties.

query: What are the effects of excluding grazing animals on plant biodiversity in grasslands and shrublands in Mediterranean climates?
relevant_summary:
Based on evidence from studies in Mediterranean climates (Israel and Spain), excluding grazing animals has mixed effects on plant biodiversity in grasslands and shrublands. For plant abundance, studies found that areas with cattle, sheep, goats, or alpacas excluded generally showed higher biomass, cover, or abundance of some or all plant groups compared to grazed areas (Action 2292, Action 1417). However, some studies also found lower biomass, cover, or abundance of certain plant groups in areas with grazers excluded compared to grazed areas (Action 2292, Action 1417).

Regarding plant diversity, the effects vary considerably. Some studies in Israel and Spain found more species, or fewer non-native species, in areas with cattle or sheep excluded compared to grazed areas (Action 2292, Action 1417). Conversely, other studies in these regions found fewer species or native species, larger decreases in the number of species, or smaller increases in the number of species, in areas with cattle, sheep, or alpacas excluded compared to grazed areas (Action 2292, Action 1417). Additionally, some studies found higher plant diversity or different community composition in plots with cattle excluded compared to grazed plots, while others found no difference in plant diversity between excluded and grazed plots (Action 2292, Action 1417).

Studies also examined different grazing intensities rather than complete exclusion. In Chile and Israel, lower grazing intensities resulted in higher cover of some plant species, herbaceous plants, or native plants compared to higher intensities, though some plant groups showed lower cover or biomass with reduced grazing (Action 2294). Plant diversity responses to grazing intensity varied, with some studies finding no differences between different cattle-grazing intensities, while one study in Chile found fewer native species and more non-native species in paddocks with lower sheep-grazing intensities (Action 2294).

Implementation options (1 study): One replicated site comparison in shrubland in Spain found less carbon and nitrogen in untilled soils that were grazed, compared to ungrazed, but found no differences in tilled soils that were grazed or ungrazed."

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Plants (9 studies)

Abundance (9 studies): Six studies (four replicated, randomized, and controlled) in grasslands or wood pasture in the USA, Chile, and Israel found higher cover of some species of plants, herbaceous plants, or native plants in areas grazed by cattle or sheep at lower, compared to higher, intensities. One controlled study in forest in Israel found higher cover of woody vegetation in areas with lower grazing intensity. Four of these studies also found lower cover or biomass of some groups of plants in sites with lower grazing intensity. Four studies in grasslands in the USA and Israel found no effect of grazing intensity on biomass, cover, or abundance of plants.
Diversity (4 studies): Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies in grasslands and wet grasslands in the USA and Israel found no differences in plant diversity between sites with different cattle-grazing intensities, in some or all comparisons. One of these also found higher diversity in some comparisons and lower diversity in others. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in wet grasslands in the USA found that plant community composition differed in sites with different cattle-grazing intensities, in some comparisons. Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies in grasslands and wet grasslands in Israel and the USA found no differences in the number of plant species between sites with different cattle grazing intensities, in some or all comparisons. One of these studies also found more species in some comparisons and fewer species in others. One controlled study in wood pasture in Chile found fewer native species and more non-native species in paddocks with lower sheep-grazing intensities.
Survival (3 studies): Three controlled studies (two replicated and randomized) in grasslands in the USA and forests in Israel found no difference in native grass, tree, or shrub survival in areas grazed by cows at lower, compared to higher, intensities."

{
  "action_id": "3956",
  "action_title": "Cease grazing on grassland to allow early succession",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-six studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of ceasing grazing on grassland to allow early succession. Five studies were in the UK, four were in each of Germany and the USA, three were in each of Sweden and Finland, two were in each of Spain and the Czech Republic, and one was in each of Switzerland, Europe and Israel.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (14 STUDIES)

Community composition (3 studies): Two replicated, site comparison studies in the Czech Republic and Germany found that the community composition of butterflies and moths in grasslands which had been abandoned for >5 years or an unspecified length of time was similar to grasslands managed by grazing or mowing (results not distinguished). One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in Spain found that after grazing and mowing management was abandoned, over 6 years the butterfly community became dominated by generalist species, and species with fewer generations/year.
Richness/diversity (12 studies): Six of nine replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study, one paired, site comparison, and seven site comparisons) in Germany, the USA, Finland, Sweden and the Czech Republic found that grasslands which had been not been grazed for >5 years, or an unspecified length of time, in one case with burning, had a similar species richness of butterflies and day-flying, burnet or all moths to grasslands grazed by cattle, horses and cattle or a mix of livestock (in two studies grazing and mowing were not distinguished) or grazed with cattle and burned. One of these studies also found that grasslands abandoned for 5–15 years had a greater species richness than grasslands grazed by sheep. A further two studies found that grasslands which had been abandoned for >5–20 years or many years had a lower species richness of butterflies than grazed grasslands (in one study grazing and mowing were not distinguished). The other study found that butterfly species richness was higher in grasslands where grazing ceased 2–9 years ago than those abandoned >10 years ago or those currently grazed. Three replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study and two site comparison studies) in Switzerland, Germany and the UK found that grasslands which had been abandoned for 4, 5–10 or >10 years had a higher species richness of butterflies and day-flying moths and nocturnal moths than extensively grazed, recently abandoned or commercially grazed grasslands. Two of these studies also found that grassland abandoned for 4 or 5–10 years had a similar species richness of butterflies and day-flying moths and all moths to grassland lightly grazed by cattle or sheep/sheep and cattle.

POPULATION RESPONSE (24 STUDIES)

Abundance (24 studies): Six of 20 replicated studies (including one paired, controlled, before-and-after study, three randomized controlled studies, and 15 site comparison studies) in Germany, the USA, the UK, Switzerland, Finland, Sweden, Spain, the Czech Republic and Israel found that grasslands which had been abandoned for 1-25 years had a higher abundance of Scotch argus, butterflies and day-flying moths, nocturnal moths, caterpillars, and of small insects including caterpillars, than grasslands grazed by goats, sheep and/or cattle. Two of these studies only found a difference compared to grazing at commercial/intensive, not low, densities. Four of the studies found that grasslands which had been abandoned for two weeks, 5–20 years or an undetermined time had a lower abundance of butterflies and spring webworm caterpillars than grasslands grazed by cattle or a mix of livestock (in two studies grazing and mowing were not distinguished). A further four of the studies found that grasslands which had been abandoned for 5-15 years had a similar abundance of butterflies, burnet moths, day-flying moths and meadow neb moth caterpillars to grasslands grazed by sheep, horses and cattle or a mix of livestock. A further four of the studies found that in grasslands which had been abandoned for >10 years, many years or an unspecified number of years, and in one case with burning, abundance or density was mixed depending on butterfly and moth species compared to grasslands grazed by cattle or unspecified grazers or grazed with cattle and burned. The other study found that butterfly density was higher in grasslands where grazing ceased 2–9 years ago than those abandoned >10 years ago or those currently grazed. Two replicated studies (including one controlled, before-and-after study and one site comparison study) in Spain and Germany found that grasslands which had been abandoned for 1–6 years or an unspecified time period had a higher abundance of woodland and hedgerow butterflies and burnet moths, but a lower abundance of grassland or farmland species, than grasslands managed by grazing and/or mowing (results not distinguished). Two studies also found that the large blue and silver-studded blue went extinct in some abandoned meadows. One replicated, site comparison study in Sweden found that grasslands which were ungrazed for the year had a lower abundance of clouded Apollo butterflies than lightly grazed grasslands, but a higher abundance than heavily grazed grasslands. One review in Europe reported that ceasing grazing on grassland benefitted six out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern.

BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)

Use (3 studies): One replicated, paired, site comparison study in Germany found that grassland which had been abandoned for >5 years had a similar occurrence of hoary bell moth caterpillars to grassland grazed by sheep. One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that a similar proportion of grasslands which had been abandoned for one year, and grazed grasslands, contained >20 marsh fritillary caterpillar webs. One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found that grizzled skipper and painted lady occurred less frequently, but small pearl-bordered fritillary occurred more frequently, in meadows which had been abandoned for at least 1–2 years than in meadows managed by grazing or mowing (results not distinguished)."
}
